Detailed Description

template<class T>
class Sylph::Collection< T >

A Collection represents a group of objects, known as its elements.

Some collections allow duplicate elements and others do not. Some are ordered and others unordered. This interface is used to pass around the various Collection classes, such as Vector, and erm... -- well there are more to come -- around with a maximum generality. Most Collection s do the same thing (holding data) and the abstraction layer provided here makes dealing with different types of Collection s easy.

All "destructive" methods (those not marked as const ) are allowed to throw an UnsupportedOperationException. Collection that do not allow NULL (0) elements are allowed to throw NullPointerException s . Collection s that are backed by Array s are allowed to throw ArrayException s if the underlying Array gets an out-of-bounds error.

Member Function Documentation

template<class T>
virtual Iterator Sylph::Collection< T >::iterator (  )  const [pure virtual]

Get an instance of the Iterator for this class.

The iterator returned is not mutable, i.e. it cannot modify the contents of the collection.

Unless mutability is really required, it is recommended to prefer this method, as it does not allow accidential modifications.

Returns:
An Iterator specific for the class being iterated over.

Implements Sylph::Iterable< T >.

template<class T>
virtual MutableIterator Sylph::Collection< T >::mutableIterator (  )  [pure virtual]

Get an instance of the MutableIterator for this class.

The iterator returned is mutable, i.e. it can modifiy the contents of the collection.

Returns:
An MutableIterator for the class being iterated over.

Implements Sylph::Iterable< T >.
